Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> they are angry that more people are getting FPGA's, ruining their daily profits

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Haha,

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> I saw that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> the company quoted $14/day profit mining VRSC, as of 11/28/2018

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> they call it "algo1" everywhere

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> it's down to around $5 or less, i heard

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> those numbers use a 0.10/kwh elec cost, as per their hosting

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Yeah, so they can just mine something else I guedd

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Perhaps they will ruin a good thing and find some other coin to suck off of

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> @Godballz hahahaha

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Probably

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> VerusHash seems to be one of the most power efficient algorithms to run on the F1

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> @dukeleto you mentioned there are more powerful fpgas with more ram which are also currently mining vrsc. what is your source for that comment?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> @John Westbrook the internet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> F1's are very tiny/inexpensive FPGAs, is one point. There exist "pro" FPGAs, that cost more than your car

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> Those FPGAs, people can program to mine any coin. Like Verus

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> those people don't share their bitstreams, they write them for themselves, and paid customers, and maybe hedge funds or VC people

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> Blackminer F1 is like the iphone, but some people use ham radio

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ibCtdVmPAas

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> that is probably a $50K fpga rig

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> you can reprogram it while it's running

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> i don't even have to power down my machine to follow your fork, when I have the right bitstream

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> if I owned such a thing ðŸ˜ƒ I don't.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Yeah, I have watched many videos of people with super expensive fpga rigs and talking about private bitstreams and secret bitstreams

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Think logically, if someone had a killer algo, why share it early?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> the above evidence shows, if you just knock off F1s from the network, you are just disabling the tiniest FPGA's

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> you are not disabling professional FPGAs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> concentrating the power into smaller group of richer miners is worse, right?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> I thought you said "people have verushash bitstreams for more expensive fpgas..."

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> @dukeleto depends on the affect on the community.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> who has verushash bitstreams for more expensive fpgas?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> I did say that. It's a very reasonable estimation. I have no proof written in blood for you

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> lol, not after your blood

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> Whoever writes them will make lots of money, therefore somebody has written it or is writing it.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> @dukeleto I believe the same thing after looking at the videos of fpga rigs.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Until fpga becomes mainstream they are just decentralization vampires. It seems foolish to leave nearly half of verus hash coinbase Rewards to the hands of the few who own fpga that is centralization by definition and seems counterintuitive to what the project began as

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> what is happening now, is FPGAs are becoming trivially easy to use

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> The thing is, fpgas need very skilled developers to creat new algos all the time. So, I doubt the top ones will ever be mainstream. Just half way like f1 miner.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Do you know how to program an fpga?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> FPGAs have existed since much before Bitcoin was invented. It's now becoming mainstream. Less optimized than ASICs, but they are so flexible, as to be more useful

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> not trivially to program, trivial to mine with, i should say

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> I can't program anything, lol

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Ah, how do you use it?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> ssh?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> it acts just like a Z9 mini or similar. Web interface

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> The black miner f1 comes with a team of miners and developers

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> almost the same ugly GUI as bitmain, better css ðŸ˜‰

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> No need for coding skills by the customwr

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> you upload various coins you want to mine, select the coin, and set pool details + mine

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> I've never used any ASIC so I don't have a reference point

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Do you mine to a pool?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> you can only support a few coins at a time, so you can add and subtract them, even while it's running

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> you create your own pool or mine to a public pool

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Hmm, interesting.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> And what if the algo changes?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lK2aACwneks&t=652s

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Is this an "on site" thing you need to handle?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> that $20/day was verushash, i believe

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> @John Westbrook you seem kind of confused, maybe because you haven't mined a bunch. Go look at some YT videos, it should explain how simple they are to use

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> "if the algo changes" is what we have been talking about for the last 16hrs or so ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <ok88> @dukeleto FPGAs are around for a few years, it's just the accessibility that changes now indeed. We did have fpgas in 2013/2014 already. I believe there are good ones that have a solid bitstreams and are mining popular algos. My concern in here is just the fact, that we are such a newb community and quite a fresh coin and that FPGAs right now could really screw us badly in terms of organic growth of community. BTW. they are in the network for over a month now so we should not panic this much, it's done. The question is: do we want to deal with it somehow

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> I only have mined using GPUs and CPUs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> My question to that end is how easy is it from the interface to update to the next algo

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> @ok88 FPGAs existed when I started mining BTC in 2011, only custom built ones by "BTC gods" of the time, like ArtForz

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Is it automated? Do you download it?  I wasn't in this conversation all 16 hours ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> @John Westbrook clicking 3 buttons, maybe 2

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> it's like installing a new driver on your computer. they call it "flashing a new bitstream"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> And is bitstream the service they update the algo through to you?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> a bitstream is just an .exe for an FPGA

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Ah, okay

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> it's a binary executed on the hardware

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Do you have to stop mining to do this?  And for how long?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> @ok88 well the way I felt with it is to sell it all and keep an eye not this project and how it develops

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> you must load the bitstream into the FPGA, for it to execute. Like a bios update

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> @John Westbrook like I said, no. You can live update coins, no downtimes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> live updates is built into the hardware

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Ah, interesting

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> of all FPGAs, it seems

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> Maybe we need to learn from the experience of projects which claim to FPGA resistance? Surely there are ready-made solutions from other projects

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> it's not specific to the blackminer. The FPGA knows how to update it's own BIOS while it's running, essentially

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> a few parts of the FPGA are dedicated to nothing but updating while running

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> We don't need to be FPGA resistant, it's more about maintaining decentralization, accessiblity to new hardware, and reasonable support for casual miners

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> @Takoy_Nahal

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> @John Westbrook agreed, but can't see how all can be maintained with fpgas

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Cool, thanks for the answers @dukeleto, I have zero experience with an fpga as I said, but sounds like a fun process to learn

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> @John Westbrook Then you want to sit on two chairs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> constant source code updates to invalidate existing bitstreams. But from the developer perspective, it's a nightmare. Also a nightmare for pools and exchanges

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> exchanges will charge verus money for every update, pools will go down, some pools will not be able to keep up

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> The only viable option I see is Verus Foundation itself making an FPGA miner, that is better in some way. Even if it's about the same, most people would rather give money to Verus community than an fpga company

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> Verus could strategically make a few small changes, on the way there, to give some temporary breathing room. That alone though, is not a full strategy, in my opinion

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> It is impossible to please everyone, I've never seen such a hashing algorithm where fairly distributed coins among CPU, GPU and FGPA miners, it's impossible. Someone will be slighted. So if to choose between two bad options I would have opposed FPGA fully

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Also, by the way, on the topic of hashes and hardware, hope everyone saw @Chris - LOUD Mining Dev-Ops impressive update to ccminer! ~27%  improvement I think?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> What do you mine with @Takoy_Nahal ?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> GPU/POS. Now only POS
